Designing a web catalogue to improve a ‘hardware purchase experience’.

DHM Wheels is an old, Mumbai-based business dealing in a wide range of castor wheels & trolleys. Their product catalogues have always been disorganised, misleading & jargon-heavy doing neither customers, not the store owners any good.

It was in this context that's we started to build a website— to provide the customer with a clean, consolidated & comprehensible product catalogue. One that would help them make better informed, hardware purchases.

DHM Wheels is a family business. So this project kept getting pushed down the priority list, as and when other projects came in. Having said that, lifelong observations & conversations with dad, eventually materialised into designs that went through multiple phases of dormancy, but slowly continued to evolve over a couple of years. Finally, I decided to develop the website, and in doing that, experiment with an exciting new library I had discovered (at the time), called React.js.

2-3 years later here we are. Plenty of learnings— in critiquing the approaches of a younger me, in bringing back momentum to a stagnated piece time and again, in implementing not-so-straight-forward design specifications in the form of code, using a whole new component-based web development approach, and much more. I’ll keep what follows, brief.

Duration
2-3 phases of 2-3 months over 2-3 years
Client
DHM Wheels
Role
Information Design . UX-UI . Web Development
Core Team
Abrar. Just Me.
Outcomes
Website Design & Development

Defining the Scope

The scope of the project was simple— to clear out the clutter from the catalogues, and provide the customers with a much smaller, crisper version of products that actually tend to move off the shelves.

In addition to that, to provide the customers with the right bits of supporting information & guidance, so that they can make informed product choices, and immediately enquire about them through the portal. We intentionally left out e-commerce functionalities due to the high customisability of each product and therefore, their variable pricing.

Process

As I mentioned earlier, the ‘process’ in a sense has been on for many years, if one is to consider the casual observations and conversations I have made, over the years, with stakeholders in the business. But, once I actively started working on the project, the usual steps of:

Market Research
What are others doing and what can we learn from them.

Information Design
In this case, it meant sifting through several not-so-appealing catalogues, filtering out the noise, and creating organised excel sheets of products, model numbers, key dimensions, descriptive copy, other meta data, etc.

Wireframes & Visual Design
Where the interface starts taking form.

Web Development
Initially, there was no process to this really. I had a new library called React.js in my hands, and I intended to build the website to pixel perfection using it. So mostly, trying-failing-succeeding-moving on, was the name of the game. Eventually however, once I got familiar with React, I organised myself and started tackling the development in the form of sprints.

All of this of course, was peppered with tests, feedback sessions & reiterations. Once we go live with a beta version of the website, the intention is to develop a more formalised testing framework, and continue with the test & iterate approach.

Outcome

A web portal that helps DHM wheels’ customers, to make better informed hardware purchases, by presenting them with a clean, consolidated & comprehensible product-catalogue-experience.

Highlights

As a one man team, I was handling all the different pieces that make a website— data, content, UX, UI, Web Development. So from designing the website, to cleaning up and consolidating catalogue data, scrounging for product images and cleaning them up, and then finally bringing it all to life using react.js— this ‘coming to life’ was definitely the highlight. Since it was a slow-moving side-project, I never quite thought it would make it to this stage. But it did.

Next highlight will be when we go live with the website.

Challenges Faced

The highlight was that all the work came alive in the form of code. But to bring it to this stage was quite a challenge, considering my knowledge of web development at the time, was limited to simple HTML, CSS and hardcoding content.

My first technology choice in fact, was Laravel— A PHP Framework. I’m not sure why. I found myself lost on it, and eventually abandoned the project. A while later I was introduced to React.js and the entire concept of a ‘single page application’ sounded exciting. And so I gave it a shot.

Current Status

We’re about a month away from a beta release. Finally. Then we test, and iterate accordingly.
